item.title: Atari 2600+ And Atari 400 Mini Hit Lowest Prices Ever For Black Friday
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/atari-2600-and-atari-400-mini-hit-lowest-prices-ever-for-black-friday/1100-6528028/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Amazon is already slashing prices for Black Friday, and right now you’ll find two popular retro gaming consoles discounted to their lowest prices of the year. Swing by the online retailer and you can pick up the Atari 400 Mini for $100 (was $120) and the Atari 2600+ for just $110 (was $130). The Atari 7800+ also arrives on Friday--so consider snagging a preorder to round out your retro console collection.

Atari 400 Mini

$100 (was $120)

What’s great about the Atari 400 Mini is that it can emulate all Atari 8-bit systems, including the 400, 800XL, and 5200. The console has been fully modernized, featuring 720 HD output, HDMI support, and the option to play in a variety of aspect ratios. You can also enable a retro CRT filter to give your games a retro flair. It comes with 25 built-in games, though you can also play games via USB flash drive. This console includes a CXStick joystick, which is a recreation of the iconic Atari CX40.

Atari 2600+

$110 (was $130)

The Atari 2600+ offers many of the same features as its smaller cousin, such as HDMI support, a joystick, and 10 games included with your purchase. Best of all, the Atari 2600+ offers full support for Atari 2600 and 7800 games thanks to a functional cartridge slot. That makes this a great way to check out your old Atari collection, though you’ll also find games for sale in case yours are no longer in working condition.

Shopping for a modern console? Check out the best PlayStation Black Friday deals, as you’ll find not just the console discounted, but also controllers, headsets, and video games. The same goes for Xbox Series X and Xbox Series S, with both seeing great deals ahead of Black Friday.

item.title: Call Of Duty Now Lets You Become A Muscly Shark
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/call-of-duty-now-lets-you-become-a-muscly-shark/1100-6528027/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Activision has released the latest operator bundle for Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and Warzone, and it's none other than a shark. The "G'Day Bait Tracer Pack," as it's called, allows players to morph into a menacing-looking shark, but that's not all.

The bundle (via One Esports) includes two weapon blueprints and a number of exclusive cosmetics. The operator skin is called "Bloke Biter," and it transforms the operator Carver into a scary shark with huge muscles. The weapon blueprints included in the bundle are themed around the ocean and water. There are additional water-themed cosmetics to help make it look like you escaped from the depths.

This DLC bundle costs 24,000 COD Points, which is about $20 USD. You can get a closer look at the "G'Day Bait Tracer Pack" in the video below.

The in-game Call of Duty shop is regularly updated with new bundles, and the shark operator isn't the only new arrival. Peter Stormare's character, The Replacer, is now available in the store as well, and he has some of the most ridiculous finishing moves we've ever seen in Call of Duty.

Black Ops 6 launched at the end of October and was the month's best-selling game in the US, and is already the No. 3 best-selling game of 2024 so far.

In other Call of Duty news, it's been reported that Microsoft has created a new committee to help shape the future of the mega-franchise.

item.title: God Of War Rumors Shut Down By Kratos Actor Christopher Judge
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/god-of-war-rumors-shut-down-by-kratos-actor-christopher-judge/1100-6528025/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Actor Christopher Judge, who plays Kratos in Sony's God of War series, has shut down a rumor about the future of the series. Writing on social media, Judge said rumors that he teased news about the God of War series during a recent Instagram Live are "absolutely not true."

He said, "You can't tease something you know nothing about."

During an Instagram Live, Judge said his fans can look forward to news about his next projects soon. He never mentioned God of War or Sony, but that didn't stop some from theorizing he might have been teasing a new God of War project.

"I will be making announcements in the near future; I can guarantee none of them will be about OUR beloved God of War," he said, adding that, like fans, he's waiting to hear about what's next for the series.

Absolutely not true! You can’t tease something you know nothing about. I will be making announcements in the near future, I can guarantee none of them will be about OUR beloved God of War. I am awaiting updates just like everyone else. ❤️ https://t.co/CNPWcmnXCW

— Christopher Judge (@iamchrisjudge) November 25, 2024

Sony's latest God of War saga focused on Norse mythology and spanned two games--it won't become a trilogy. Judge starred in both games as Kratos, with Sunny Suljic playing Atreus. Judge won Best Performance at the 2022 Game Awards, and his embrace with Oscar-winner Al Pacino made headlines.

The last God of War game was 2022's God of War Ragnarok, and it was made by Sony Santa Monica. The studio has not announced any new projects, but series veteran Cory Barlog has teased his next game, and it could be a new IP.

item.title: Cyberpunk 2077 Player Spends Way Too Long Maxing Level Before Even Starting The Main Campaign
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/cyberpunk-2077-player-spends-way-too-long-maxing-level-before-even-starting-the-main-campaign/1100-6528026/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

One Cyberpunk 2077 player has taken on the challenge of reaching the max level in the game before they start the mission that kicks off the main campaign. How long did it take them? A staggering 40 hours and 30 minutes of grinding--an impressive feat given the restrictions in place during the early parts of the game before starting the mission that sets V on their path and introduces Johnny Silverhand.

Reddit user uO__Ou detailed how they first completed the handful of introductory missions in Cyberpunk 2077 and how they then used an exploit to escape the Watson area so that they could focus on reaching the level cap of 50.

At this early point in the game, the various gigs and missions aren't available to players yet, but engaging in various activities in certain areas helped uO__Ou slowly grind away and earn experience points. "Go to Pacifica, Batty's Hotel for, in my experience, the best farming spot," the determined Cyberpunk 2077 player explained. "Repeat it over and over and over. Took me 40 hours but to be honest, if I did this more efficiently, it can take me less than 35 hours. Just don't forget to sleep every hour for [an] XP boost and to use different weapons, for your sanity and for skill progression."

It is much easier in the main campaign as opposed to constantly fighting gangsters in Pacifica, as campaign missions reward players with generous amounts of experience points. As noted by the game-tracking website How Long to Beat, Cyberpunk 2077 takes, on average, over 25 hours to complete the primary story, but with all of that hard work, most of the game should be a walk in the park for uO__Ou now.

If you're morbidly curious and you want to spend a few days grinding away, you can grab Cyberpunk 2077 and its Phantom Liberty expansion for just $40 during Black Friday, on PS5 and Xbox Series X.

In related news, don't expect to see Cyberpunk 2077 upgraded for PS5 Pro, but you can--technically--play the upcoming sequel early when CD Projekt Red hosts playtests for it in the future.

item.title: Sony Reportedly Developing A PS5 Portable System
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/sony-reportedly-developing-a-ps5-portable-system/1100-6528023/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

A successor (of sorts) to PlayStation Portable and PS Vita is reportedly in development at Sony. The company is apparently working on a handheld PS5 system that would seemingly compete with Nintendo's upcoming Switch 2 and Valve's Steam Deck.

According to Bloomberg, the PS5 portable system is years away from hitting the market--if it does at all. There is still a possibility Sony decides to pull the plug on the handheld. The report states that the PlayStation Portal was originally planned as a similar product to Steam Deck before becoming dependent on streaming via a PS5 console. However, a new PlayStation Portal update has introduced a cloud-streaming beta for PS Plus Premium members. This means a PS5 isn't required to play games on the device.

Sony isn't alone in wanting to expand to the handheld market. Microsoft Gaming CEO Phil Spencer has been very open about his desires for an Xbox handheld, though it, too, is "a few years out," if it ever releases. Meanwhile, Nintendo will likely unveil the Switch 2 in the coming months, and the company confirmed the upcoming system will be backward compatible with the current Switch earlier this month.

A possible PS5 portable system would see Sony returning to the handheld market for the first time since launching PS Vita in Japan in 2011 (coming to North America in early 2012). The system was discontinued in Japan in early 2019, before the PS5 was released.

Before that, the PlayStation Portable came out in Japan in 2004 and North America in 2005. That Sony handheld competed with Game Boy Advance and Nintendo DS throughout the mid- to late-2000s.

item.title: The Simpsons Hit & Run Dev Gives Tragic Update On Why We Never Got A Sequel
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/the-simpsons-hit-run-dev-gives-tragic-update-on-why-we-never-got-a-sequel/1100-6528022/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

2003's The Simpsons: Hit & Run is a beloved classic game that never got a sequel, and now another key detail has come to light that probably won't make fans very happy to hear.

Lead designer Joe McGinn said in an interview with Summoning Salt that Radical Entertainment wanted to make a sequel. In fact, McGinn said the studio had the rights for three sequels for no additional licensing fee.

"Gracie Films offered our publisher a deal to make three sequels, with all Simpsons rights and voice actors, for the preferred price of zero dollars (we wouldn't have to pay anything for the Simpsons license in other words)," McGinn said (via GamesRadar).

Given that, anyone might have predicted that Radical would move forward with a sequel--but it wasn't meant to be. "Some crazy person at the publisher [Vivendi Games]--we never found out who--said no," McGinn said.

No further information was divulged in the interview about this, so we may never know who that person was or why they said no to making a sequel (or two). The game is reported to have sold as many as 10 million units over its lifetime, which certainly sounds like enough to justify a sequel. However, there could be countless reasons for why a sequel never materialized.

Hit & Run is fondly remembered and remains popular to this day, in part thanks to the speedrunning community. "We never imagined it would still be bringing some people happiness 20 years later!" McGinn said.

After Radical released Hit & Run in 2003, the studio launched licensed titles like CSI: Miami for Ubisoft, Scarface: The World is Yours with Vivendi, and later original games Prototype and Prototype 2 with Activision. Its last project was supporting Bungie on the original Destiny.

Given the rise in remakes and re-releases of video games in recent times, some are wondering if the 2003 game might be next in line. It's too soon to say, but McGinn previously said he would "love" to see that.

Radical and Vivendi Games have both closed up shop, so any remake would seemingly have to come from a different developer and publisher. It's not immediately clear who owns the video game rights to The Simpsons franchise.

Electronic Arts published 2007's The Simpsons Game based on the film, as well as the mobile title The Simpsons: Tapped Out in 2012 (that game was delisted in October and ends service this coming January). The TV series is still on the air, but no announcements have been made about future video games.

Hit & Run was the second major Simpsons game from Radical, following 2001's Simpsons: Road Rage, which wasn't nearly as beloved as Hit & Run.

item.title: Silent Hill 2's Latest Patch Addresses PS5 Pro Performance Issues
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/silent-hill-2s-latest-patch-addresses-ps5-pro-performance-issues/1100-6528015/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The PlayStation 5 Pro came out of the gate earlier this month with its $700 price tag and a list of PS5 Pro-enhanced game that was supposed to offer early adapters a peak gaming experience. However, players soon reported that Silent Hill 2, Star Wars Jedi: Survivor, and other games actually looked worse on PS5 Pro. Now, Konami and developer Bloober Team have addressed the issues on a new patch for Silent Hill 2.

Silent Hill 2's 1.06 patch wasn't just created for the PS5 Pro problems. It's also adjusting and fixing a few issues with the PC version on Steam, but the PS5 Pro fixes are the highlight here. Prior to this update, Silent Hill 2 players on PS5 Pro noticed a number of glitches and visual distortions that weren't happening to the game on standard PlayStation 5 consoles.

Ironically, this is not the first time a Silent Hill 2 update has led to more problems than fixes. Silent Hill 2's 1.04 patch was intended to improve the game's performance on Steam and cut down on crashes on PS5. Unfortunately, it also introduced a few game-breaking bugs that were meant to be dealt with as of the 1.05 patch. But that's when players noticed the issues with the game's performance on PS5 Pro.

To the credit of Konami and Bloober Team, the new patches have been released relatively quickly. Hopefully any future issues will also be addressed in a speedy manner. Given the early difficulties that some developers have had with PS5 Pro-enhanced games, it's not shocking that CD Projekt Red decided not to create a PlayStation 5 Pro patch for Cyberpunk 2077 anytime soon.
